concerns.answer: AI summarization captures all major findings, methods, and conclusions. You can always read the full paper if the summary indicates it's highly relevant. This is actually more efficient than reading everything in full.

Modern AI (like Google Gemini) has excellent reading comprehension, often matching or exceeding tired human readers. The key is using AI for initial screening, then manual reading for critical analysis.

concerns.concern: Won't I lose the reading practice?
concerns.answer: No - you'll read more strategically. Instead of struggling through 50 mediocre papers, you'll deeply engage with the 10-15 most relevant papers. Quality over quantity.

faq.question: Can AI summarization replace reading papers?
faq.answer: No - AI summarization is a screening tool, not a replacement. Use AI to quickly identify the most relevant papers, then read those papers in full. This strategy saves time while maintaining deep understanding.

faq.question: How much time does AI summarization really save?
faq.answer: For a 20-page paper: AI takes 2-3 minutes vs 45-60 minutes manual reading (90% time savings). For 50 papers: 2-3 hours with AI vs 37-50 hours manual (92% time savings).

faq.question: Is AI summarization accurate enough for research?
faq.answer: Yes for initial screening and literature reviews. Modern AI accurately identifies key findings, methods, and conclusions. Always verify critical information by reading the original source for your core analysis.

faq.question: When should I still read papers manually?
faq.answer: Read manually when: papers are directly relevant to your research, you're evaluating methodology, you need to critique the work, or you're building on specific findings. Use AI for initial screening and background research.
